prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: n6240_b3_co10
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Target: NGC 6240 Band: 3 CO transition: J = 1 - 0 Angular resolution: 0.6 arcsecond Rms: 1 mJy Velocity resolution: 30 km/s

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The CO(1-0) strongest peak flux is estimated by SMA CO(3-2) flux (~2.14 Jy/beam; 2.0 * 1.8 beam) and Herschel CO(3-2)/CO(1-0) ratio (~ 20; Rosenberg et al. 2015). In order to detect all the gas structures (i.e., not only the nuclei but also the extended wing which has a 1/3 peak of the nuclei; Iono et al. 2007; Feruglio et al. 2012) with at least S/N ~ 3, we request a sensitivity of 1 mJy (expected peak of the nuclei = 2140 / 20 * (0.6*0.6/(2.0*1.8)) ~ 10.7 mJy/beam).
The same applies to the comntinuum, while the expected 115 GHz flux is estimated by using the 345GHz peak flux (42 mJy/beam with 1.8" * 1.6" beam; Iono et al. 2007) and the Rayleigh-Jeans approximation (42 * (115.3/345.8)^2 * (0.6*0.6/(1.8*1.6)) ~ 0.58 mJy/beam).

We require 30 km/s resolution in order to separate GMA-scale structures using 3D datacube (0.6" and 30 km/s cube). This will be performed by using the CLUMPFIND method (Williams et al. 1994). Comparing with other-J CO datacube will help us to idensify gas clumps in the 3D datacube.

For NGC 6240 (luminosity distance = 103 Mpc), the requested angular resolution (0.6") is consistent with ~ 300 pc. This is enough to resolve large giant molecular associations (GMAs) in nearby LIRGs which typically have 200 - 500 pc diameters (e.g., high-resolution studies provided by Konig et al. 2013; Xu et al. 2015).
The largest angular scale is provided by PdBI observations of CO(1-0) emission (Feruglio et al. 2012).

The CO(2-1) strongest peak flux is estimated by SMA CO(3-2) flux (~2.14 Jy/beam; 2.0 * 1.8 beam) and Herschel CO(3-2)/CO(2-1) ratio (~ 3; Rosenberg et al. 2015). In order to detect all the gas structures (i.e., not only the nuclei but also the extended wing which has a 1/3 peak of the nuclei; Iono et al. 2007; Feruglio et al. 2012) with at least S/N ~ 10 (for robust determination of excitation parameters), we request a sensitivity of 2 mJy (expected peak of the nuclei = 2140 / 3 * (0.6*0.6/(2.0*1.8)) ~ 71 mJy/beam).
The same applies to the comntinuum, while the expected 230 GHz flux is estimated by using the 345GHz peak flux (42 mJy/beam with 1.8" * 1.6" beam; Iono et al. 2007) and the Rayleigh-Jeans approximation (42 * (230.5/345.8)^2 * (0.6*0.6/(1.8*1.6)) ~ 2.3 mJy/beam).

We require 10 km/s resolution in order to separate GMA-scale structures using 3D datacube (0.6" and 10 km/s cube). This will be performed by using the CLUMPFIND method (Williams et al. 1994). Comparing with other-J CO datacube will help us to idensify gas clumps in the 3D datacube.

For NGC 6240 (luminosity distance = 103 Mpc), the requested angular resolution (0.6") is consistent with ~ 300 pc. This is enough to resolve large giant molecular associations (GMAs) in nearby LIRGs which typically have 200 - 500 pc diameters (e.g., high-resolution studies provided by Konig et al. 2013; Xu et al. 2015).
The largest angular scale is provided by SMA observations of CO(3-2) emission (Iono et al. 2007).

The CO(3-2) strongest peak flux is estimated by SMA CO(3-2) flux (~2.14 Jy/beam; 2.0 * 1.8 beam). In order to detect all the gas structures (i.e., not only the nuclei but also the extended wing which has a 1/3 peak of the nuclei; Iono et al. 2007; Feruglio et al. 2012) with at least S/N ~ 10 - 30 (for robust determination of excitation parameters), we request a sensitivity of 2 mJy (expected peak of the nuclei = 2140 * (0.6*0.6/(2.0*1.8)) ~ 214 mJy/beam).
The same applies to the comntinuum, while the expected 345 GHz flux is estimated by using the 345GHz peak flux (42 mJy/beam with 1.8" * 1.6" beam; Iono et al. 2007) and the Rayleigh-Jeans approximation (42 * (0.6*0.6/(1.8*1.6)) ~ 5.25 mJy/beam).

We require 10 km/s resolution in order to separate GMA-scale structures using 3D datacube (0.6" and 10 km/s cube). This will be performed by using the CLUMPFIND method (Williams et al. 1994). Comparing with other-J CO datacube will help us to idensify gas clumps in the 3D datacube.

For NGC 6240 (luminosity distance = 103 Mpc), the requested angular resolution (0.6") is consistent with ~ 300 pc. This is enough to resolve large giant molecular associations (GMAs) in nearby LIRGs which typically have 200 - 500 pc diameters (e.g., high-resolution studies provided by Konig et al. 2013; Xu et al. 2015).
The largest angular scale is provided by SMA observations of CO(3-2) emission (Iono et al. 2007).

The CO(6-5) strongest peak flux is estimated by SMA CO(3-2) flux (~2.14 Jy/beam; 2.0 * 1.8 beam) and Herschel CO(6-5)/CO(3-2) ratio (~ 3; Rosenberg et al. 2015). In order to detect extended the nuclear components which detected in the SMA CO(3-2) emission for robust determination of excitation parameters, we request a sensitivity of 10 mJy (expected peak of the nuclei = 2140 * 3 * (0.6*0.6/(2.0*1.8)) ~ 642 mJy/beam).
The same applies to the comntinuum, while the expected 691 GHz flux is estimated by using the 345GHz peak flux (42 mJy/beam with 1.8" * 1.6" beam; Iono et al. 2007) and the Rayleigh-Jeans approximation (42 * (691.5/345.8)^2 * (0.6*0.6/(1.8*1.6)) ~ 21 mJy/beam).

We require 30 km/s resolution in order to separate GMA-scale structures using 3D datacube (0.6" and 30 km/s cube). This will be performed by using the CLUMPFIND method (Williams et al. 1994). Comparing with other-J CO datacube will help us to idensify gas clumps in the 3D datacube.

For NGC 6240 (luminosity distance = 103 Mpc), the requested angular resolution (0.6") is consistent with ~ 300 pc. This is enough to resolve large giant molecular associations (GMAs) in nearby LIRGs which typically have 200 - 500 pc diameters (e.g., high-resolution studies provided by Konig et al. 2013; Xu et al. 2015).
The largest angular scale is provided by SMA observations of CO(3-2) emission (Iono et al. 2007).

We require 50 km/s resolution rnough to detect GMA-scale structures using moment maps (e.g., Xu et al. 2015). We can ignore superposition of CO(7-6)-emitting clouds relative to that of the lower-J CO lines, because the CO(7-6) can be assumed to concentrate around nuclear regions. The assumption is consistent with cycle 0 NGC 6240 results of HCN(4-3), HCO+(4-3), and CS(7-6) emission (Scoville et al. 2015) Thus, we focus on achieving high sensitivity and hihg spatial resolution for the CO(7-6) line.

For NGC 6240 (luminosity distance = 103 Mpc), the requested angular resolution (0.6") is consistent with ~ 300 pc. This is enough to resolve large giant molecular associations (GMAs) in nearby LIRGs which typically have 200 - 500 pc diameters (e.g., high-resolution studies provided by Konig et al. 2013; Xu et al. 2015).
The largest angular scale is provided by SMA observations of CO(3-2) emission (Iono et al. 2007).

The CO(7-6) strongest peak flux is estimated by SMA CO(3-2) flux (~2.14 Jy/beam; 2.0 * 1.8 beam) and Herschel CO(7-6)/CO(3-2) ratio (~ 3; Rosenberg et al. 2015). In order to detect extended the nuclear components which detected in the SMA CO(3-2) emission for robust determination of excitation parameters, we request a sensitivity of 15 mJy (expected peak of the nuclei = 2140 * 3 * (0.6*0.6/(2.0*1.8)) ~ 642 mJy/beam).
The same applies to the comntinuum, while the expected 867 GHz flux is estimated by using the 345GHz peak flux (42 mJy/beam with 1.8" * 1.6" beam; Iono et al. 2007) and the Rayleigh-Jeans approximation (42 * (806.7/345.8)^2 * (0.6*0.6/(1.8*1.6)) ~ 28.6 mJy/beam).

We require 50 km/s resolution rnough to detect GMA-scale structures using moment maps (e.g., Xu et al. 2015). We can ignore superposition of CO(8-7)-emitting clouds relative to that of the lower-J CO lines, because the CO(8-7) can be assumed to concentrate around nuclear regions. The assumption is consistent with cycle 0 NGC 6240 results of HCN(4-3), HCO+(4-3), and CS(7-6) emission (Scoville et al. 2015) Thus, we focus on achieving high sensitivity and hihg spatial resolution for the CO(8-7) line.
We use 3 spws to cover the broad component (FWHI = 700 km/s) which is detected in the CO(3-2) emission (Iono et al. 2007).

For NGC 6240 (luminosity distance = 103 Mpc), the requested angular resolution (0.6") is consistent with ~ 300 pc. This is enough to resolve large giant molecular associations (GMAs) in nearby LIRGs which typically have 200 - 500 pc diameters (e.g., high-resolution studies provided by Konig et al. 2013; Xu et al. 2015).
The largest angular scale is provided by SMA observations of CO(3-2) emission (Iono et al. 2007).

The CO(8-7) strongest peak flux is estimated by SMA CO(3-2) flux (~2.14 Jy/beam; 2.0 * 1.8 beam) and Herschel CO(8-7)/CO(3-2) ratio (~ 3; Rosenberg et al. 2015). In order to detect extended the nuclear components which detected in the SMA CO(3-2) emission for robust determination of excitation parameters, we request a sensitivity of 20 mJy (expected peak of the nuclei = 2140 * 3 * (0.6*0.6/(2.0*1.8)) ~ 642 mJy/beam).
The same applies to the comntinuum, while the expected 921 GHz flux is estimated by using the 345GHz peak flux (42 mJy/beam with 1.8" * 1.6" beam; Iono et al. 2007) and the Rayleigh-Jeans approximation (42 * (921.8/345.8)^2 * (0.6*0.6/(1.8*1.6)) ~ 37.3 mJy/beam).

VV 114 has extended gas structures traced in the CO(3-2) emission (Saito et al. 2015). Most of peaks located in the entire system (i.e., extranuclear gas clumps) are ~ 1/10 of the strongest peak (~ 8 mJy). The CO(2-1) strongest peak flux is estimated by cycle 0 ALMA CO(3-2) flux (~1 Jy/beam; 1.6 * 1.2 beam) and Herschel CO(3-2)/CO(2-1) ratio (~ 1; Rosenberg et al. 2015). In order to detect all the gas structures with at least S/N ~ 4, we request a sensitivity of 2 mJy (expected peak flux of extranuclear gas clumps = 83 / 10 ~ 8 mJy).
The same applies to the comntinuum, while the expected 231 GHz flux is estimated by using the 345GHz flux (Saito et al. 2015) and the Rayleigh-Jeans approximation.
We require 10 km/s resolution in order to separate GMA-scale structures using 3D datacube (0.6" and 10 km/s cube). This will be performed by using the CLUMPFIND method (Williams et al. 1994).

For VV 114 (luminosity distance = 80 Mpc), the requested angular resolution (0.6") is consistent with ~ 300 pc. This is enough to resolve large giant molecular associations (GMAs) in nearby LIRGs which typically have 200 - 500 pc diameters (e.g., high-resolution studies provided by Konig et al. 2013; Xu et al. 2015).
The largest angular scale is provided by cycle 0 ALMA observations of CO(3-2) emission (Saito et al. 2015).
We require 50 km/s resolution in order to separate GMA-scale structures using 3D datacube (0.6" and 10 km/s cube).

For VV 114 (luminosity distance = 80 Mpc), the requested angular resolution (0.6") is consistent with ~ 300 pc. This is enough to distinguish nuclear gas clumps separated by a mean projected distance of ~ 600 pc (Iono et al. 2013).
The largest angular scale is provided by SMA observations of CO(6-5) emission (Sliwa et al. 2013).

VV 114 has an unresolved component traced in the CO(6-5) emission (3.1 * 2.2 beam; Sliwa et al. 2013), so that we can assume the CO(7-6) emission should be compact. The CO(7-6) strongest peak flux is estimated by the SMA CO(6-5) flux (~1.8 Jy/beam; 3.1 * 2.2 beam) and Herschel CO(7-6)/CO(6-5) ratio (~ 1; Rosenberg et al. 2015). In order to constrain excitation parameters of the unresolved component robustly, we request a sensitivity of 15 mJy (S/N ~ 6; expected peak CO(7-6) flux = 1800 * 1 * (0.6*0.6/(3.1*2.2)) ~ 95 mJy/beam).
The same applies to the comntinuum, while the expected 807 GHz flux (30.11 mJy) is estimated by using the 345GHz flux (2.62 mJy; Saito et al. 2015) and the Rayleigh-Jeans approximation. Since we will perform SED fitting using sub-mm continuum emission with other data (e.g., HST, Herschel), we need at least ~ 10 sigma for all frequencies in order to fit several components (e.g., beta, temperature...).
We require 50 km/s resolution in order to separate GMA-scale structures using 3D datacube (0.6" and 10 km/s cube).

For VV 114 (luminosity distance = 80 Mpc), the requested angular resolution (0.6") is consistent with ~ 300 pc. This is enough to distinguish nuclear gas clumps separated by a mean projected distance of ~ 600 pc (Iono et al. 2013).
The largest angular scale is provided by SMA observations of CO(6-5) emission (Sliwa et al. 2013).

VV 114 has an unresolved component traced in the CO(6-5) emission (3.1 * 2.2 beam; Sliwa et al. 2013), so that we can assume the CO(8-7) emission should be compact. The CO(8-7) strongest peak flux is estimated by the SMA CO(6-5) flux (~1.8 Jy/beam; 3.1 * 2.2 beam) and Herschel CO(7-6)/CO(6-5) ratio (~ 0.8; Rosenberg et al. 2015). In order to constrain excitation parameters of the unresolved component robustly, we request a sensitivity of 12 mJy (S/N ~ 6; expected peak CO(7-6) flux = 1800 * 0.8 * (0.6*0.6/(3.1*2.2)) ~ 80 mJy/beam).
The same applies to the comntinuum, while the expected 807 GHz flux (39.38 mJy) is estimated by using the 345GHz flux (2.62 mJy; Saito et al. 2015) and the Rayleigh-Jeans approximation. Since we will perform SED fitting using sub-mm continuum emission with other data (e.g., HST, Herschel), we need at least ~ 10 sigma for all frequencies in order to fit several components (e.g., beta, temperature...).

NGC 1614 has a diffuse gas disk (diameter ~ 12") traced in the CO(1-0), CO(2-1), and CO(3-2) emission (Sliwa et al. 2014; Saito et al. in prep.). The peaks in the gas disk are roughly 1/15 of the strongest peak. The CO(4-3) strongest peak flux is estimated by the cycle 0 ALMA CO(3-2) flux (~0.29 Jy/beam; 0.57 * 0.41 beam) and Herschel CO(4-3)/CO(3-2) ratio (~ 1; Rosenberg et al. 2015). In order to constrain excitation parameters of the gas disk robustly, we request a sensitivity of 5 mJy (S/N ~ 6; expected peak CO(4-3) flux of the disk = 290 * 1 * (0.6*0.6/(0.57*0.41)) / 15 ~ 30 mJy/beam).
For comntinuum, the expected 461 GHz flux (9.0 mJy) is estimated by using the 345GHz flux (3.3 mJy; Saito et al. in prep.) and the Rayleigh-Jeans approximation. Since we will perform SED fitting using sub-mm continuum emission with other data (e.g., HST, Herschel), we need at least ~ 10 sigma for all frequencies in order to fit several components (e.g., beta, temperature...).

We require 30 km/s resolution in order to separate GMA-scale structures using 3D datacube (0.6" and 30 km/s cube). This will be performed by using the CLUMPFIND method (Williams et al. 1994). Comparing with the high resolution CO(2-1) (0.8" and 3 km/s; Saito et al. in prep.) and CO(6-5) (0.2" and 10 km/s; Xu et al. 2015), the accuracy of clump identifications will increase.

For NGC 1614 (luminosity distance = 66 Mpc), the requested angular resolution (0.8") is consistent with ~ 300 pc. This is enough to resolve large giant molecular associations (GMAs) in nearby LIRGs which typically have 200 - 500 pc diameters (e.g., high-resolution studies provided by Konig et al. 2013; Xu et al. 2015).
The largest angular scale is provided by cycle 0-2 ALMA observations of CO(1-0), CO(2-1), and CO(3-2) emission (Saito et al. in prep.).

Our goal is to resolve desnse clumps which distribute over the entire system, so that we dare to resolve out extended/ambient CO(4-3) structures (i.e., uv-truncation). It will allow us to compare the compact CO(4-3) with the dense clumps traced in high-J CO lines without any comntaminations from diffuse gas components.

The required 50 km/s resolution for the CO(7-6) observation is enough to resolve GMA-scale structures without any superpositions along the velocity axis, because NGC 1614 shows a nearly face-on dense gas ring traced in the CO(6-5) (Xu et al. 2015).

For NGC 1614 (luminosity distance = 66 Mpc), the requested angular resolution (0.8") is consistent with ~ 300 pc. This is enough to aresolve large giant molecular associations (GMAs) in nearby LIRGs which typically have 200 - 500 pc diameters (e.g., high-resolution studies provided by Konig et al. 2013; Xu et al. 2015).
The largest angular scale is provided by cycle 0 ALMA observations of CO(6-5) emission (Xu et al. 2015).

NGC 1614 has a starburst ring (diameter ~ 2") traced in the CO(6-5) emission (Sliwa et al. 2014; Saito et al. in prep.). Using Herschel CO(7-6)/CO(6-5) ratio (~ 1; Rosenberg et al. 2015), we estimate that the typical peak CO(7-6) fluxes in the ring are 150 mJy/beam (0.6" beam). In order to constrain excitation parameters of the gas disk robustly, we request a sensitivity of 10 mJy (S/N ~ 15).
For comntinuum, the expected 807 GHz flux (28.0 mJy) is estimated by using the 345GHz flux (3.3 mJy; Saito et al. in prep.) and the Rayleigh-Jeans approximation. Since we will perform SED fitting using sub-mm continuum emission with other data (e.g., HST, Herschel), we need at least ~ 10 sigma for all frequencies in order to fit several components (e.g., beta, temperature...).

The required 50 km/s resolution for the CO(8-7) observation is enough to resolve GMA-scale structures without any superpositions along the velocity axis, because NGC 1614 shows a nearly face-on dense gas ring traced in the CO(6-5) (Xu et al. 2015).

For NGC 1614 (luminosity distance = 66 Mpc), the requested angular resolution (0.8") is consistent with ~ 300 pc. This is enough to aresolve large giant molecular associations (GMAs) in nearby LIRGs which typically have 200 - 500 pc diameters (e.g., high-resolution studies provided by Konig et al. 2013; Xu et al. 2015).
The required 0.8" resolution is not achieved by any antenna configurations with band 10 (~ 922 GHz), so that we choose 0.7" resolution at this time. When we analyze the data, we carefully look the uv coverage (e.g., Saito et al. 2015) to make the largest recoverable scale uniform.
The largest angular scale is provided by cycle 0 ALMA observations of CO(6-5) emission (Xu et al. 2015).

NGC 1614 has a starburst ring (diameter ~ 2") traced in the CO(6-5) emission (Sliwa et al. 2014; Saito et al. in prep.). Using Herschel CO(8-7)/CO(6-5) ratio (~ 1; Rosenberg et al. 2015), we estimate that the typical peak CO(7-6) fluxes in the ring are 150 mJy/beam (0.6" beam). In order to constrain excitation parameters of the gas disk robustly, we request a sensitivity of 10 mJy (S/N ~ 10).
For comntinuum, the expected 922 GHz flux (36.0 mJy) is estimated by using the 345GHz flux (3.3 mJy; Saito et al. in prep.) and the Rayleigh-Jeans approximation. Since we will perform SED fitting using sub-mm continuum emission with other data (e.g., HST, Herschel), we need at least ~ 10 sigma for all frequencies in order to fit several components (e.g., beta, temperature...).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Recent single-dish and Herschel/SPIRE observations have successfully detected high-J CO emission (e.g., J = 4-3 up to 30-29) from nearby IR bright galaxies. The resultant CO excitation diagram is called the CO spectral line energy distribution (SLED). The gas excitation is usually modeled by a combination of an ISM model of cosmic-ray dominated regions, photon dominated regions (PDRs), X-ray dominated regions (XDRs), and mechanically dominated regions (MDRs) which are dominated by galactic-scale shocks. Analysis of single dish observations is successful in fitting the CO SLED with multiple components, which then provides the global contribution from each component; however, due to the coarse single-dish and SPIRE/FTS beam (~ 10 kpc), the CO SLED contains contribution from all of the molecular gas along the line-of-sight and one cannot convincingly determine the exact contribution from each component. The main goal of this proposal is to use spatially resolved CO observations of multiple J-transitions in order to investigate the powering source in three local U/LIRGs.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Graduate School of Science, The University of Tokyo
